citeinfo.title: Changes in Anthropogenic Influences on Streams and Rivers: Housing and Population Density

descript.abstract: This dataset consists of a table of data representing housing unit density for ten year periods from 1970 to 2010 and population density for ten year periods from 1990-2010, for Hydrologic Unit Code 10 (HUC-10) areas.
descript.purpose: These data are intended to provide a framework in which watershed-specific studies of water quality in streams and rivers may be analyzed. The focus of the data is on anthropogenic changes over time.
descript.supplinf: One comma-separated text file is given here. The file contains a "uniqid" field, which is the link to the data in all other datasets in this product. Each file has 15,458 rows. Two time series are given here: one for population density, in units of persons per square kilometer (sq km) and one for housing unit density, in units of housing units per sq km. It is believed the data are comparable over time. The 1990 and 2000 population data are from the SILVIS Lab, University of Wisconsin-Madison (http://silvis.forest.wisc.edu/maps/wui), downloaded in 2005 (original data no longer posted), but transformed into rasters and published by Falcone (2016). These were 2000 block-level population data, and 1990 block-level data transformed to correspond to 2000 block boundaries, so as to be directly comparable at the block scale. (Some Census block boundaries change from era to era). Census blocks are the most detailed geographic scale for Census data. The 2010 population data are taken directly from the U.S. Census Bureau (U.S. Census Bureau, 2012) and are based on 2010 block boundaries. However, it is believed that aggregated over HUC-10 watershed areas, such as published here, the differences between 2000 and 2010 block boundaries are negligible. The housing data for 1970-2000 are also taken from SILVIS data (http://silvis.forest.wisc.edu/data/1940-2030-housing-density-pbg, Hammer and others, 2004), and are based on modeled data from information in the 2000 Census. They were derived at a consistent geographic scale, which Hammer and others (2004) created and refer to as the "partial block group" scale - not as detailed as blocks, but more detailed than block groups. The 2010 housing data are estimates in the SILVIS dataset, but are believed to be reasonably accurate, and preferable to have all data from the same source dataset. HUC-10 boundaries were obtained on January 9, 2018 from the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) National Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) at https://nrcs.app.box.com/v/huc/folder/39640323180 (National Resources Conservation Service, 2017). References: Falcone, J.A., 2016, U.S. block-level population density rasters for 1990, 2000, and 2010: U.S. Geological Survey data release, http://dx.doi.org/10.5066/F74J0C6M. Hammer, R. B. S. I. Stewart, R. Winkler, V. C. Radeloff, and P. R. Voss. 2004, Characterizing spatial and temporal residential density patterns across the U.S. Midwest, 1940-1990. Landscape and Urban Planning 69: 183-199. National Resources Conservation Service, 2017, Watershed boundary dataset (WBD): National Resources Conservation Service, U.S. Department of Agriculture, available at https://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/main/national/technical/nra/geo/, accessed January 9, 2018 from https://nrcs.app.box.com/v/huc/folder/39640323180. U.S. Census Bureau, 2012, U.S. Census Bureau 2010 block population and housing data. U.S. Census Bureau, accessed October 2012 at ftp://ftp2.census.gov/geo/tiger/TIGER2010BLKPOPHU.

citeinfo.title: U.S. block-level population density rasters for 1990, 2000, and 2010

srcinfo.srccontr: Source data from which 1990 and 2000 population density data were derived

citeinfo.title: U.S. block-level population density rasters for 1990, 2000, and 2010

srcinfo.srccontr: Source data from which 2010 population and housing data were derived.
Source data from which 1970-2000 housing unit density was derived.

procstep.procdesc: (1) Source data for the 1970-2010 housing unit density data was downloaded from SILVIS Lab at http://silvis.forest.wisc.edu/data/1940-2030-housing-density-pbg in polygon format. These were converted to 100-meter (m) integer national raster grids, one for each decade.

(2) 2010 population and housing counts were downloaded from: ftp://ftp2.census.gov/geo/tiger/TIGER2010BLKPOPHU. This ftp site contains shapefiles of census blocks by state with 2010 population and housing counts. An area field was added to each state shapefile and calculated as area in square kilometers. A population density field was added to each state shapefile and the census source fields POP10 and HU10 were divided by the area field to get population density in persons per square kilometer, and housing density in housing units per square kilometer, respectively. The shapefiles were then converted to 60-m rasters based on the population density and housing unit density fields. The rasters were merged to create a national raster.
(3) Source rasters for 1990 and 2000 population density were obtained from Falcone, 2016. These were already-prepared block-level 100-m resolution rasters of population density for those eras.
(5) HUC-10 watershed housing and population density was calculated using the zonalmean() command in ArcGIS Grid.
